segment.source: Manage TPM commands (Windows 10)
segment.target: Manage TPM commands (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to manage which Trusted Platform Module (TPM) commands are available to domain users and to local users.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to manage which Trusted Platform Module (TPM) commands are available to domain users and to local users.

segment.source: Manage TPM commands
segment.target: Manage TPM commands

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes how to manage which Trusted Platform Module (TPM) commands are available to domain users and to local users.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes how to manage which Trusted Platform Module (TPM) commands are available to domain users and to local users.

segment.source: After a computer user takes ownership of the TPM, the TPM owner can limit which TPM commands can be run by creating a list of blocked TPM commands.
segment.target: After a computer user takes ownership of the TPM, the TPM owner can limit which TPM commands can be run by creating a list of blocked TPM commands.

segment.source: The list can be created and applied to all computers in a domain by using Group Policy, or a list can be created for individual computers by using the TPM MMC.
segment.target: The list can be created and applied to all computers in a domain by using Group Policy, or a list can be created for individual computers by using the TPM MMC.

segment.source: Because some hardware vendors might provide additional commands or the Trusted Computing Group may decide to add commands in the future, the TPM MMC also supports the ability to block new commands.
segment.target: Because some hardware vendors might provide additional commands or the Trusted Computing Group may decide to add commands in the future, the TPM MMC also supports the ability to block new commands.

segment.source: Domain administrators can configure a list of blocked TPM commands by using Group Policy.
segment.target: Domain administrators can configure a list of blocked TPM commands by using Group Policy.

segment.source: Local administrators cannot allow TPM commands that are blocked through Group Policy.
segment.target: Local administrators cannot allow TPM commands that are blocked through Group Policy.

segment.source: For more information about this Group Policy setting, see TPM Group Policy settings.
segment.target: For more information about this Group Policy setting, see TPM Group Policy settings.

segment.source: Local administrators can block commands by using the TPM MMC, and commands on the default block list are also blocked unless the Group Policy settings are changed from the default settings.
segment.target: Local administrators can block commands by using the TPM MMC, and commands on the default block list are also blocked unless the Group Policy settings are changed from the default settings.

segment.source: Two policy settings control the enforcement which allows TPM commands to run.
segment.target: Two policy settings control the enforcement which allows TPM commands to run.

segment.source: For more information about these policy settings, see TPM Group Policy settings.
segment.target: For more information about these policy settings, see TPM Group Policy settings.

segment.source: The following procedures describe how to manage the TPM command lists.
segment.target: The following procedures describe how to manage the TPM command lists.

segment.source: You must be a member of the local Administrators group.
segment.target: You must be a member of the local Administrators group.

segment.source: To block TPM commands by using the Local Group Policy Editor
segment.target: To block TPM commands by using the Local Group Policy Editor

segment.source: Open the Local Group Policy Editor (gpedit.msc).
segment.target: Open the Local Group Policy Editor (gpedit.msc).

segment.source: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.
segment.target: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.

segment.source: Note: Administrators with appropriate rights in a domain can configure a Group Policy Object (GPO) that can be applied through Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).
segment.target: Note: Administrators with appropriate rights in a domain can configure a Group Policy Object (GPO) that can be applied through Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).

segment.source: In the console tree, under Computer Configuration, expand Administrative Templates, and then expand System.
segment.target: In the console tree, under Computer Configuration, expand Administrative Templates, and then expand System.

segment.source: Under System, click Trusted Platform Module Services.
segment.target: Under System, click Trusted Platform Module Services.

segment.source: In the details pane, double-click Configure the list of blocked TPM commands.
segment.target: In the details pane, double-click Configure the list of blocked TPM commands.

segment.source: Click Enabled, and then click Show.
segment.target: Click Enabled, and then click Show.

segment.source: For each command that you want to block, click Add, enter the command number, and then click OK.
segment.target: For each command that you want to block, click Add, enter the command number, and then click OK.

segment.source: Note: For a list of commands, see the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) Specifications.
segment.target: Note: For a list of commands, see the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) Specifications.

segment.source: After you have added numbers for each command that you want to block, click OK twice.
segment.target: After you have added numbers for each command that you want to block, click OK twice.

segment.source: Close the Local Group Policy Editor.
segment.target: Close the Local Group Policy Editor.

segment.source: To block or allow TPM commands by using the TPM MMC
segment.target: To block or allow TPM commands by using the TPM MMC

segment.source: Open the TPM MMC (tpm.msc)
segment.target: Open the TPM MMC (tpm.msc)

segment.source: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.
segment.target: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.

segment.source: In the console tree, click Command Management.
segment.target: In the console tree, click Command Management.

segment.source: A list of TPM commands is displayed.
segment.target: A list of TPM commands is displayed.

segment.source: In the list, select a command that you want to block or allow.
segment.target: In the list, select a command that you want to block or allow.

segment.source: Under Actions, click Block Selected Command or Allow Selected Command as needed.
segment.target: Under Actions, click Block Selected Command or Allow Selected Command as needed.

segment.source: If Allow Selected Command is unavailable, that command is currently blocked by Group Policy.
segment.target: If Allow Selected Command is unavailable, that command is currently blocked by Group Policy.

segment.source: To block new commands
segment.target: To block new commands

segment.source: Open the TPM MMC (tpm.msc).
segment.target: Open the TPM MMC (tpm.msc).

segment.source: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.
segment.target: If the User Account Control dialog box appears, confirm that the action it displays is what you want, and then click Yes.

segment.source: In the console tree, click Command Management.
segment.target: In the console tree, click Command Management.

segment.source: A list of TPM commands is displayed.
segment.target: A list of TPM commands is displayed.

segment.source: In the Action pane, click Block New Command.
segment.target: In the Action pane, click Block New Command.

segment.source: The Block New Command dialog box is displayed.
segment.target: The Block New Command dialog box is displayed.

segment.source: In the Command Number text box, type the number of the new command that you want to block, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Command Number text box, type the number of the new command that you want to block, and then click OK.

segment.source: The command number you entered is added to the blocked list.
segment.target: The command number you entered is added to the blocked list.

segment.source: Use the TPM cmdlets
segment.target: Use the TPM cmdlets

segment.source: If you are using Windows PowerShell to manage your computers, you can also manage the TPM by using Windows PowerShell.
segment.target: If you are using Windows PowerShell to manage your computers, you can also manage the TPM by using Windows PowerShell.

segment.source: To install the TPM cmdlets, type the following command:
segment.target: To install the TPM cmdlets, type the following command:

segment.source: For details about the individual cmdlets, see TPM Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell
segment.target: For details about the individual cmdlets, see TPM Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell

segment.source: Additional resources
segment.target: Additional resources

segment.source: For more info about TPM, see Trusted Platform Module technology overview.
segment.target: For more info about TPM, see Trusted Platform Module technology overview.
